Subjective: Spot on neck for 2 weeks. Started as small wound post-shaving, also an insect bite in the area. Now swollen and redder. Intermittent itching. Scabs form and fall off. No pain. No similar spots elsewhere. PMH: Warts, ear abscess removal. FH: Paternal family hx of sun-related skin problems, type unknown. Concern for skin cancer after online search. Request: Wants lesion identified and removed; prefers freezing over excision if an option. Also notes knee pain after running for months, deferred to future appt.
Objective: Skin: Single, raised, pinkish-red lesion on neck, approx. 0.5 cm. Redder spot in center. No visible scab or flaking on exam. Remainder of neck skin shows some freckles. Dermoscopy performed. Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy.
Assessment: Uncertain skin lesion, neck. Differential diagnosis includes pyogenic granuloma vs. atypical mole.
Plan: 1. Photo of lesion to be sent for dermatology e-consultation.
2. Await dermatologist's advice on diagnosis and management.
3. Discussed potential removal options with patient: cryotherapy, excision, or curettage with biopsy.
4. Follow-up: Will call patient on Friday (before 10 AM or after 3 PM) with dermatologist's recommendation. Patient consents to voicemail if unavailable.
5. Advised to schedule a separate appointment to address knee pain if it persists.
